content: The "Reforming Alternatives to Incarceration and Sentencing to Establish a Better Path for Youth Act of 2015" or the "RAISE Act of 2015" provides a safety valve for nonviolent youth. Section 3553 of title 18, United States Code, allows courts to impose a sentence below a statutory minimum for youth convicted of nonviolent offenses if it would result in substantial injustice and is not necessary for public protection. The court must consider factors such as the nature of the crime, the youth's history, characteristics, and chances of successful rehabilitation. Before imposing such a sentence, the court must give parties notice. Section 3553 of title 18, United States Code, allows courts to impose a sentence below a statutory minimum for youth convicted of nonviolent offenses. The court must consider factors such as the nature of the crime, the youth's history, characteristics, and chances of successful rehabilitation. The court must provide reasonable notice and an opportunity to respond before imposing such a sentence. The written statement of reasons must include the factors requiring a sentence below the statutory minimum. This subsection does not limit any right to appeal. SEC. 3. Early release and home confinement for youth. Section 3624 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to allow for early release and home confinement for prisoners, including youth prisoners. The amendment specifies the conditions and duration for home confinement, with certain limitations. The amendment to Section 3624 of title 18, United States Code allows for early release and home confinement for prisoners, with specific conditions and limitations. Placement in a community correction center cannot be used instead of home confinement solely based on mental health diagnosis. There is a presumption for direct release to home confinement unless the Bureau of Prisons Director determines otherwise in writing. Prisoners on home confinement cannot be required to pay for electronic monitoring. Additionally, the Bureau of Prisons is required to release certain youth prisoners early. The Bureau of Prisons is mandated to release youth prisoners who have served at least half of their sentence for nonviolent offenses and have not violated disciplinary regulations involving violence in the last 2 years. "Youth" refers to individuals 21 years old or younger at the time of the offense, and "nonviolent offense" excludes crimes of violence or sex offenses. In cases of youth serving long sentences, a court may reduce imprisonment after 20 years based on extraordinary reasons, including rehabilitation efforts. The legislation allows for the consideration of rehabilitation efforts and the age of youth in determining sentences for offenses carrying mandatory life imprisonment. The legislation considers the age of individuals 21 years or younger at the time of the criminal offense for sentencing or imprisonment. SEC. 5. SMARTER PROBATION FOR YOUTH. Amendment to Section 3565 of title 18, United States Code, allows for reduced imprisonment for technical probation violations. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and potentially amend Federal sentencing guidelines. Amend Federal sentencing guidelines for probation and supervised release under section 3565 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 6. Specialized housing and programs for youth in correctional facilities to separate them from other offenders and provide specific education, training, and mental health programs tailored to their needs. SEC. 7. Pilot programs for youth. The Bureau of Prisons will establish pilot programs for youth in at least 10 judicial districts, including mentorship, government service, and service to vulnerable animals. The Attorney General will establish pilot programs for high-risk youth and victimized youth to avoid criminal conviction through intensive case management and community services. Additionally, a program will equip youth with skills to provide training and therapy to animals seized by Federal law enforcement or organizations that shelter vulnerable animals. The pilot programs aim to help high-risk youth and victimized youth avoid criminal conviction through intensive case management and community services. The Attorney General will report to Congress on the results, including cost savings and recidivism rates among participants. The terms "youth" and "nonviolent offense" are defined in this section. The Act and its amendments apply to youth involved in the Federal criminal justice system regardless of when they became involved.
